nodes.text: Infinite exponential economic growth is essential for the survival and conservation of our economy and civilization
Dominant anti-growth perspective asserts entropy production (Second Law) imposes fundamental limits that make infinite growth impossible and environmentally destructive
Dominant pro-growth perspective asserts knowledge, ideas, and technological innovation can decouple growth from material resource limits and enable (potentially infinite) growth
Both dominant perspectives are limited and talk past each other because anti-growth privileges entropy as ontologically primary and pro-growth privileges a Cartesian mental/material dualism

A broader inclusive perspective centered on the universal process of creation (equilibration producing new levels of organization) resolves the controversy and supports the necessity and possibility of infinite exponential growth
Anti-growth policies (reducing population, production, consumption) are socially painful, politically unpopular, and lack clear mechanisms to preserve civilization despite acknowledging entropy
Anti-growth perspective misinterprets entropy as solely destructive and overlooks that equilibration can produce new organization and disequilibrium at higher levels
Pro-growth proponents rely on an ontological distinction between mental (knowledge) and material operations and treat mental production as immune or irrelevant to entropy

Critique: mental and physical operations are not ontologically separate; mental operations originate from physical sensory-motor processes and thus are subject to entropy-like depletion of resources (e.g., diminishing research productivity)
Because both perspectives fail to analyze the process that creates radical novelty, they cannot guide policy toward sustaining civilization
Process-of-creation claim: equilibration of n functional operations generates an n squared number of combinations, producing exponential increases in organizational power and new resources
Conservation thesis: sustaining a regulatory level of organization requires creating new higher levels of organization to access new resources and preserve the existing level
Consequence: failing to achieve exponential growth leads to exponential decline in productivity, exponential resource depletion, and exponential population growth as compensatory response

Empirical evidence: studies (Bloom et al.) show research productivity falls over time, requiring exponential increases in researchers to sustain constant growth, indicating idea-finding is getting harder

Policy implication and conclusion: organizing social and economic practice around the intentional, conscious process of creation and fostering inclusion will enable infinite exponential growth and thus conserve civilization
Limitation: achieving intentional systemic reorganization requires overcoming exclusionary social practices, institutional inertia, and limited understanding of creativity processes
